> 1. One seed is given and it should crawl within this particular
> domain only
>
The scope in the configuration below should work for this.

> 2. Should fetch only MIME type text/html pages which matches a
> particular RegExp
>
You had the right idea in the configuration below, but processors  
consider a DecideRule that returns PASS to mean the same thing as  
ACCEPT.

In your configuration below, the midfetch-rules will usually result  
in a decision of PASS, since neither the  
ContentTypeMatchesRegexpDecideRule nor the MatchesRegExpDecideRule  
will match most URIs. FetchHTTP will interpret the PASS result to  
mean the same as ACCEPT.

You'll want to do two things.

First, since the MatchesRegExpDecideRule won't be affected by HTTP  
headers, you want to move it to HTTP:decide-rules instead of  
HTTP:midfetch-rules.

Next, you want to prepend a RejectDecideRule to the front of both  
HTTP:decide-rules and HTTP:midfetch-rules. That will cause URIs to be  
rejected by default. Only those that match the regexp in  
MatchesRegExpDecideRule will have their headers fetched, on only  
those whose content-type header matches  
ContentTypeMatchesRegExpDecideRule will have their content fetched.

> 3. Should write only MIME type text/html pages which has StatusCode
> of 200 and matches a particular RegExp
>
Similarly you need to prepend a RejectDecideRule to the front of  
Archiver:decide-rules, so that ARCWriterProcessor rejects everything  
that doesn't match the later rules.

-Paul
